sub_body:
So I’m gonna start this off by saying that I haven’t had my MRIs yet. But they’re already calling this a demylineating disease. 

I saw the neurologist for the first time in September. I had about a week and a half of numbness in my right arm and two days of numbness in my right leg after I looked down too quickly at work. They gave me an emg and told me all was normal and to come back if the symptoms happened again. 

So two weeks ago I had been getting raging headaches up until now. I’m not a headache person but they were there and definitely hard to ignore. Throw in a little bit of double vision and I still wasn’t concerned. However, last week while still getting the headaches, I woke up with the worst stiff neck I could ever imagine. It didn’t let up for 5 days. As soon as the neck happened, my numb arm and face came back with a vengeance. 

Yesterday I figured I might as well follow up with neuro so they took me in that day. I ended up seeing a nurse practitioner that works under the neuro who did my EMG. During this visit she said I had a positive babinski result that I hadn’t had back in September. As we were going over everything and doing the exam, she said that she wants to do a brain MRI and left the exam room to consult neurologist. He was pretty loud when he was speaking and he told her “sounds like MS. Don’t tell her it is so she doesn’t freak out but do a brain and neck MRI with and without contrast.” 

She came back in and told me she thinks it’s a demylineating disease and said that my symptoms sound like MS but they just want to make sure before they say for sure. So now I’m waiting for insurance to approve the MRIs. 

I’m so afraid and I don’t want to freak out my husband so I haven’t really talked to him about it. Just told him about the MRIs. I wish they didn’t act so definitive without imaging me yet. I’m only 21. Queue depression mode.

comments.comment_body: Try not to worry about it too much. In a way it might be better if you have ms rather than something they aren’t able to diagnose yet because the research for it has come leaps and bounds in the last 20 or so years. Many people with ms can live a pretty full life with not too many adjustments especially if it’s tackled early. I’m 23 and have only started my treatment very recently, but keep your chin up; whether you have ms or not, it’s going to be ok.

comments.comment_body:
I'm sorry for what you're enduring.  

I think I speak for many when I say that the diagnosis experience is very scary and stressful: even if one gets in for a MRI, and information soon after, it still takes a couple of weeks of waiting and wondering.  For some it's the not knowing which leads to anxiety and frustration.  Then again, knowing isn't the most wonderful, either; but then you can work through the grief process to the point of acceptance.  And yes, it is grief - a lament for the "little death" of the way you thought life was going to go, and a particular view of yourself.  

If it is MS, there are treatments and therapies which help manage the condition.  It's no one's idea of a good time, of course; but it's not a death sentence.  

I will say that this is a time when you will need your people to rally around you.  This is not a condition easily faced alone.  It may not be time yet to tell your husband, but it will be at some point.

Please let us know how it all turns out.

comments.comment_body: Wow, just wow. I know this fear. Was just diagnosed last year. Believe it was April... May... Not a hundred percent because between insurance and doctors I was constantly in fear. The unknown is scarier than anything. Please know, I'm praying for you today. I am hurting with you, and your in your pain, at no time are you alone. Time can seem like it's going too slowly while in fear and transfixed on what the actual fuck is happening to me? But try if you can to surround yourself with support and be open with people, including the one you live with... Point is, I hope that your tests come back positive, but know that if they don't you don't need to be ashamed. We have all been there and the road isn't always straight and narrow. Just the fact that you shared here: you're stronger than you ever know! Keep yourself moving along and you'll be amazed at what you can do!

comments.comment_body: Omg I feel like we are kindred spirits! I'm going through the process of getting an official diagnosis and getting a bunch of tests. I feel the fear and anxiety of the unknown. Unfortunately, it seems like MS is a diagnosis of the unknown - anything could happen at anytime. I know that doesn't help but I've been trying to focus on gratitude while processing this bombshell. If you need someone to commiserate or celebrate with I'm here for you. I'm scared too.

comments.comment_body: I know buddy, I’m the same age and when I was first diagnosed I was in the same place, terrified, depressed and felt like I was alone in the world. However trust me when I say things will get better, I’m a year on now and I can honestly life seems a little lighter, my work helps distract me with a boss who is so supportive, family and friends who are unbelievably supportive as well. Everyone still has their bad days and it goes back to feeling like you’re back in the dark place but you’ll pull through and all these people here on this sub are here for you as well, it’s a good resource to have and use.

comments.comment_body: One thing to keep in mind is no matter what the end result of your MRI, you'll be able to get through this. Not knowing is the worst feeling, even knowing is tough... but there are a lot of things you can do to make life manageable even with a demyelinating disease. I know it's scary, but do your best to keep calm. The stress you're feeling now will subside eventually. My suggestion is try and find someone you trust to talk through your thoughts with. A sounding board is an amazing resource.

I know how scary it must seem. Whatever is going on, it’s best to know though. Once you know what it is, you can hopefully get an appropriate treatment going. 

If it is MS then the ‘great’ news is that there are so many excellent treatments available nowadays that can slow down the progression of the disease. I really mean that. 

That doesn’t make it any easier of course. 

I hope you don’t have to wait very long for your MRIs.

sub_body_inference._doc_text:
So I’m gonna start this off by saying that I haven’t had my MRIs yet. But they’re already calling this a demylineating disease. 

I saw the neurologist for the first time in September. I had about a week and a half of numbness in my right arm and two days of numbness in my right leg after I looked down too quickly at work. They gave me an emg and told me all was normal and to come back if the symptoms happened again. 

So two weeks ago I had been getting raging headaches up until now. I’m not a headache person but they were there and definitely hard to ignore. Throw in a little bit of double vision and I still wasn’t concerned. However, last week while still getting the headaches, I woke up with the worst stiff neck I could ever imagine. It didn’t let up for 5 days. As soon as the neck happened, my numb arm and face came back with a vengeance. 

Yesterday I figured I might as well follow up with neuro so they took me in that day. I ended up seeing a nurse practitioner that works under the neuro who did my EMG. During this visit she said I had a positive babinski result that I hadn’t had back in September. As we were going over everything and doing the exam, she said that she wants to do a brain MRI and left the exam room to consult neurologist. He was pretty loud when he was speaking and he told her “sounds like MS. Don’t tell her it is so she doesn’t freak out but do a brain and neck MRI with and without contrast.” 

She came back in and told me she thinks it’s a demylineating disease and said that my symptoms sound like MS but they just want to make sure before they say for sure. So now I’m waiting for insurance to approve the MRIs. 

I’m so afraid and I don’t want to freak out my husband so I haven’t really talked to him about it. Just told him about the MRIs. I wish they didn’t act so definitive without imaging me yet. I’m only 21. Queue depression mode.

sub_body:
Hello!! I hope you are all having a nice week.

I am wondering, for those of you that practice intermittent fasting (I.F.)- How do you ensure you are not becoming malnourished, without going for blood work nonstop?

My question comes from the fact that I'm having a lot of issues around food. I am thin, but not underweight (BMI 18.5-19) and have a bit of a hard time keeping healthy weight on as I have very little appetite.

Only last week I regained my sense of taste/feeling in my mouth. I didn't ever really consciously get started with I.F., I just don't eat a lot and don't know if I'm actually doing more harm than good. 

I know I am quite B12 deficient and am overdue for a B12 shot (I self-inject this normally every month, but am still low), and also have very low Vitamin D but take supplements of that and omega 3s.

My diet looks like this in an average week:
-Black coffee (2-3 cups) and water every morning 
-Smoothie made with rice milk, tahini, berries and protein powder normally about 4 days/week.
-Snack around noon: Sunripe fruit-to-go bar
-I might have avocado on gluten free toast with butter or GF macaroni and cheese 3x/week
-Dinners: Baked Chicken (seasoned with indian spices), roasted veggies (carrots, onion, sweet potato, zucchini) and rice or GF potato gnocchi, or I'll order a GF pepperoni pizza about twice/month.

3-4 days/week I'll have some dark chocolate and/or some potato chips in the evening.

I know the things I am eating are generally healthy, I'm just afraid it's too far. *So I'm asking, is there anything that stands out that could be an easy change?*

Do you have any healthy and easy go-to meals that help lift you up and keep you sustained? 

I'm looking for suggestions for real foods and simple recipes. Any suggestions are greatly appreciated! Thanks!

comments.comment_body:
I'll never understand those who downvote others who are actively looking for help.

Whoever is that type of person, GFY.

Edited to add: I posted this comment after a series of downvotes. Really appreciated that.

Quinoa is easy, versatile, and healthy.  Same with eggs.   I love either of those mixed with fresh veggies.  Minestrone soup is a winter favorite around here -- lots of recipes online.  

I love steel cut oats, cooked in unsweetened almond milk, with vanilla and a little real maple syrup to sweeten.  Then I add chopped walnuts and cinnamon.

You could add nuts, nut butters, more variety of fruit & veggies, organic green tea.

Listen to your body.  😊  Our dietary needs can vary.

comments.comment_body:
We recently made a lentil soup that was easy, delicious and fairly nutritious! It was Alton Brown's Lentil Soup recipe. We left it chunky instead of using the immersion blender.
[Lentil Soup Recipe](https://www.epicurious.com/recipes/member/views/alton-browns-lentil-soup-52980541)

It was really yummy, and kept well for leftovers. Can be altered to be vegan, easily!

Instead of chicken you could try wild salmon every once in a while. It's full of nutrients and I think very tasty. 

Cheese and crackers is another snack you could add to your lunch. Pretty good helping of protein and calcium there, plus fat which seems a bit low in your diet. And bonus, cheese is delicious! If your lactose sensitive there are still lots of varieties without lactose, swiss for example or specialty lactose-free varieties. 

Another late night snack, cereal and milk (or oat milk, almond, etc) could add more calcium and protein and cereal is usually fortified with iron and other minerals. Some are very high in sugar but you could choose a low sugar variety if you prefer. 

I'm about the same BMI as you and I also sometimes wonder if there would be any health benefit to a slightly higher one. Oh well, at least we're in the 'healthy' range right?

comments.comment_body:
Looks like you might not be getting enough iron. I'd watch out for this one since you need B12 to absorb iron and you already know that you're deficient in that.  Low iron can also increase fatigue.

In terms of suggestions, there's lots of foods you can add to help increase iron.  I'd vary up your protein sources to include some red meat and fish.  Tofu is also a good source of non-heme iron as are lentils and beans (another reason to try /u/perenelle_flamel71 's lentil soup). Add some leafy greens to your veggie rotation, and maybe swap the rice for a fortified or brown rice. Non-heme iron (plant sourced iron) is not going to absorb as well as heme iron (animal sourced), but is still worth eating.

comments.comment_body:
There are a multitude of variants of intermittent fasting (e.g. eating only certain hours per day; skipping eating X days per week/month, etc) but you don't say what your exact strategy is.

>  as I have very little appetite.

While not a terribly common symptom, loss of appetite can be related to MS. I have gone 4 days without eating and on the morning of the 5th day waking up without a single pang of hunger. I have to remind myself to eat.

> Only last week I regained my sense of taste/feeling in my mouth.

We share some of the same, fairly uncommon, MS symptoms! :-) 

>  and easy go-to meals

To me that's a bad idea. Straight opinion, but you want *real food* and *natural food* as opposed to highly-processed, ready-to-go meals. But overall, your diet sounds sane (and yummy).

For myself, I eat *lots* (and lots!) of salads. Not only are they packed with fiber and vitamins, but they're easy to do if you follow 2 rules: (1) Always wash your veggies before you put them in the 'fridge. If they're cleaned and ready to eat in the refrigerator, that makes them "hand food" when casually looking in the 'fridge. (2) Use one of those Subway-style salad chopping bowls. I'll make salads out of whatever veggies and leftovers I have in the 'fridge and it's mindlessly quick and easy.

Iron supplements upset my stomach and digestive system, so this was an added solution (in addition to dietary adjustment) for me.

sub_body_inference._doc_text:
Hello!! I hope you are all having a nice week.

I am wondering, for those of you that practice intermittent fasting (I.F.)- How do you ensure you are not becoming malnourished, without going for blood work nonstop?

My question comes from the fact that I'm having a lot of issues around food. I am thin, but not underweight (BMI 18.5-19) and have a bit of a hard time keeping healthy weight on as I have very little appetite.

Only last week I regained my sense of taste/feeling in my mouth. I didn't ever really consciously get started with I.F., I just don't eat a lot and don't know if I'm actually doing more harm than good. 

I know I am quite B12 deficient and am overdue for a B12 shot (I self-inject this normally every month, but am still low), and also have very low Vitamin D but take supplements of that and omega 3s.

My diet looks like this in an average week:
-Black coffee (2-3 cups) and water every morning 
-Smoothie made with rice milk, tahini, berries and protein powder normally about 4 days/week.
-Snack around noon: Sunripe fruit-to-go bar
-I might have avocado on gluten free toast with butter or GF macaroni and cheese 3x/week
-Dinners: Baked Chicken (seasoned with indian spices), roasted veggies (carrots, onion, sweet potato, zucchini) and rice or GF potato gnocchi, or I'll order a GF pepperoni pizza about twice/month.

3-4 days/week I'll have some dark chocolate and/or some potato chips in the evening.

I know the things I am eating are generally healthy, I'm just afraid it's too far. *So I'm asking, is there anything that stands out that could be an easy change?*

Do you have any healthy and easy go-to meals that help lift you up and keep you sustained? 

I'm looking for suggestions for real foods and simple recipes. Any suggestions are greatly appreciated! Thanks!
